As a good alternative to cooling-based air dehumidification, Liquid Desiccant Air Conditioning (LDAC) has drawn increasing attention for energy saving in large-scale public buildings. However, available investigations mostly pay attention to the dehumidification performance analysis and optimization based on steady-state models. Dynamic control issues for LDAC are rather important to the system performance and economic cost under the changing working conditions, such as the changing setting points of indoor air conditions and sensible/latent loads in occupied space. In this study, a dynamic model based on the Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) method is established to describe the system output air temperature and humidity ratio of LDAC dynamically with varied input conditions. The verification results show that a good agreement can be found between the prediction results from the proposed model and the experimental data with the relative errors less than 2% for outlet air temperature and less than 4% for outlet air humidity ratio, respectively. An EMPC strategy is designed based on the proposed dynamic model for LDAC by solving a receding optimization problem considering tracking error, control efforts rate, and energy consumption as the objective functions with Genetic Algorithm (GA) to get optimal dynamic response and improve the energy efficiency as well. The simulation analysis shows the proposed EMPC strategy outperforms Proportional–Integral (PI) control with smaller tracking error, faster response, and higher energy efficiency. The average energy saving by the proposed EMPC strategy can reach up to 9.5%. Control of air temperature and humidity are the main tasks for providing indoor thermal comfort as the occupants’ requirements. Generally, more cooling energy with low efficiency is consumed during the dehumidification process through cooling the air lower than its dew point though air dehumidification load accounts only for a small proportion of total air-conditioning load due to the coupling between the sensible and latent loads treatments. Over the past decades, Liquid Desiccant Air Conditioning (LDAC) which has been reported to be a potential technology to the conventional cooling-based dehumidification method is receiving more and more attention since its unique advantages of ingeniously solving the coupling of air temperature and humidity treatment, environmental friendliness, high energy efficiency by utilizing low grade energy, such as industrial waste heat, geothermal energy and solar energy [1,2]. Investigations of the LDAC with high energy efficiency shows great advantages over the cooling-based dehumidification air conditioning. Currently, relevant researches mostly focus on model development [3,4,5] of the coupled heat and mass transfer process in the dehumidifier, performance analysis [6,7] by simulations and experiments, and dehumidification system design and improvements [8,9]. The most common models can be classified into three types, the finite difference model, the effectiveness-Number of Transfer Units (NTU) model, and the empirical model. The finite difference model based on differential equations of coupled heat and mass transfer process is detailed and precise. Naik et al. [10] introduced a recursive algorithm to the finite difference model to describe air dehumidification process in a cross-flow type liquid desiccant dehumidifier/regenerator. Peng et al. [11] worked on performance analysis of outside evaporative cooling liquid desiccant dehumidifier by the finite difference model. It is a big challenge for the usage of finite difference model in system optimization and control of LDAC due to the computational burden and iteration procedure during the solving process of the governing differential equations. The NTU model lightens the computational burden by introducing the Le-NTU number to the differential equations. Xie et al. [12] evaluated the effectiveness-NTU model for a counter-flow humidifier by 141 groups of experimental data with acceptable accuracy. Langroudi et al. [13] investigated theoretically and assessed the LDAC system based on the effectiveness-NTU model by employing response surface methodology. The empirical model depending on experimental data is relatively flexible with a simple form. Wang et al. [14] proposed a hybrid empirical model by extracting important characteristic parameters for real-time performance assessment and optimization of the LDAC system. Joon-Young et al. [15] evaluated the dehumidification effectiveness of LDAC system by developing an empirical model. With the steady-state models, the system supervisory optimization strategy to achieve improved energy performance of LDAC has been developed. Wang et al. [16] proposed a global optimization operation strategy to achieve energy efficiency improvement of LDAC system by employing the self-adaptive differential evolutionary algorithm. Ou et al. [17] proposed an optimization strategy with energy consumption decreased by 12.49% compared with the conventional strategy in LDAC. Tu et al. [18] worked on analyzing and optimizing the operating parameters of the LDAC system. The investigation results of LDAC optimization can help in system operation schedule under steady conditions, but they contribute little under changing operating conditions in the actual operating process. Therefore, more efforts have been made on dynamic performance analysis and dynamic model development of LDAC [19,20]. R. Namvar et al. [21] developed a dynamic numerical model to study the transient behaviors of a liquid-to-air membrane energy exchanger (LAMEE) and compared the simulation results with the ones at steady state. Li et al. [22] proposed a simplified dynamic dehumidifier model which is expected to be used for dehumidification system controller design due to the excellent performance in system dynamic behaviors prediction. Wang et al. [23] reported a transient simulation of the dehumidification performance using a dynamic heat and mass transfer model with less computational work for the LDAC system. Dynamic models with low calculation burden and high accuracy for the LDAC system can contribute to a better understanding of the system dynamic performance and becomes the basis for further studying on the system dynamic control. Few efficient control strategies to achieve both system performance optimization and energy management are available, which restrict LDAC’s application and energy-saving potential [24,25]. Therefore, it is indeed necessary to have the optimal dynamic control of supplied air temperature and humidity to cover the time-varying indoor sensible and latent loads with the minimized system energy consumption. However, researches on LDAC optimal dynamic control strategy developments are currently limited. Considerable studies on model-based and optimal control for the HVAC system [26,27] can be referred to from available publications. Razmara et al. [28] developed an exergy model for evaluating system energy efficiency and used Model Predictive Control (MPC) to reduce exergy destruction in the HVAC system. Bianchini et al. [29] devised an MPC method for efficient management of HVAC system in large-scale buildings. Similar control methods can also be employed for dynamic control and performance optimization of the LDAC system. Inherent nonlinearity and multi-variables characteristics in LDAC systems imply that the nonlinear control methods are urgently demanded. Among many advanced control methods, MPC has been regarded as an effective and powerful technique for the control of industrial process systems and considered to be very suitable for slow dynamic systems like HVAC and LDAC. Compared with standard MPC, Economic Model Predictive Control (EMPC) is a more preferred control strategy for the reason that the latter introduces the economic function to general optimization function and explores the potential to improve system profit in a practical operation process. Effective control strategy is necessary for the LDAC system to provide indoor thermal comfort as the occupants’ requirements under the changing conditions, such as variations of outdoor weather conditions and indoor sensible/latent loads. Energy efficiency improvement of the LDAC system has been paid close attention to in this paper. The main contributions of this study are concluded as follows: (1) A fuzzy predictive model based on Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) method has been established to characterize dynamic dehumidification process in LDAC system; (2) To our knowledge, EMPC is applied in Liquid Desiccant Air Conditioning (LDAC) for the first time to develop system optimal operation strategy considering both system outputs and energy efficiency, simultaneously. EMPC is used as an effective control approach to obtain the optimal control sequence for adjusting supply air state to the required values and minimize the modified receding optimization function with Genetic Algorithm (GA); (3) Energy efficiency comparisons of the LDAC system under various working conditions show that EMPC strategy can improve energy efficiency and achieve dynamic control comparing with Proportional-Integral (PI) strategy; (4) Energy-saving effects by the two control strategies in different segments have also been investigated and concluded. The outline of the paper is listed as follows. The energy-consuming model of the dehumidifier is presented in Section 2. While in Section 3, the dynamic prediction model by the ANFIS method for a dehumidifier is developed. In Section 4, we have introduced the experimental facility to validate the performance of the prediction model. In Section 5, the EMPC and PI control strategies for the LDAC system have been depicted. In Section 6, the simulation studies have been implemented and the results have been discussed. Finally, the summary of this work is given in Section 7. 2 Energy consumption model of the dehumidifier The dehumidifier is the main component of the LDAC system that provides cooled and dehumidified air to occupied space as required conditions, thus only the liquid desiccant dehumidifier is investigated in this work. The liquid desiccant dehumidifier mainly consists of a counter-flow packed type column, a chiller supplying cooling energy, a solution pump, a fan, and a strong solution tank, as the sketch map shown in Fig. 1 . Outside warm and moist air with high temperature and humidity is blown up from the bottom of the dehumidifier, meanwhile, the strong desiccant solution driven by the solution pump from the strong solution tank is sprayed on the top of the packed column after cooled through the chiller. Coupled heat and mass transfer process occurs between the warm moist air and concentrated desiccant solutions by taking temperature and surface water vapor pressure as the driving forces. Cooled and dehumidified air is fed into the occupied space to regulate the indoor temperature and humidity while desiccant solutions are distilled and pumped back to the weak solution tank and charged into regenerator to be concentrated. Under varying indoor sensible/latent loads, air with different temperatures and humidity ratios are required from the LDAC. Assume that the strong desiccant solution with fixed concentration is supplied by stable operation of the regenerator. The desiccant solution flow rate and temperature are considered as the two control variables affecting outlet air conditions of the dehumidifier. Previous literature [10,11] have reported that by increasing flow rate or reducing temperature of inlet desiccant solution to the dehumidifier, cooler and drier air can be obtained. Local feedback control strategy such as on/off and Proportional–Integral–Derivative (PID) controllers can control the outlet air temperature and humidity dynamically to satisfy the requirements by regulating the two mentioned variables but fail to consider the system energy efficiency and changes of control variables, which are closely related to system operating cost and lifetime, respectively. Thus, to have the optimal dynamic control of liquid desiccant dehumidifier, an energy model to evaluate the energy efficiency of dehumidifier under different control actions is necessary while designing the optimal controller. Chiller, pump, and fan are the components which consume electric energy in the dehumidifier. In this study, a chiller based on the vapor compression refrigerant cycle is used to cool the desiccant solution down to the temperature as the controller desired. The chiller energy consumption can be calculated by the ratio between actual cooling load and coefficient of performance (COP) [30]. The energy consumption of a chiller is formulated as follows [16]. (1) Q c = c s m s ( T s , i , c - T s , i , o ) (2) r c = Q c Q c , n o m (3) COP = r c t c + 273.5 t e - 273.5 r c + a 1 t c + 273.5 t e - 273.5 + a 2 (4) E c = Q c COP where Q c and Q c , n o m denote the current cooling load and nominal cooling load capacity, respectively; T s , i , c and T s , i , o are the inlet and outlet desiccant solution temperatures for the evaporator of chiller, respectively; r c is the ratio of current cooling load Qc and nominal cooling load Qc,nom ; t e and t c are evaporating temperature and condensing temperature, respectively. Parameters, a 1 and a 2 can be determined by experimental data with regression approach. Ec denotes the energy consumption of a chiller. Similar modeling method can be applied to the pump and fan whose energy consumptions can be estimated by the following expressions. (5) r p = m s m s , n o m (6) E p = E p , n o m ( p 3 r p 3 + p 2 r p 2 + p 1 r p + p 0 ) (7) r f = m a m a , n o m (8) E f = E f , n o m ( f 3 r f 3 + f 2 r f 2 + f 1 r f + f 0 ) where E p , E f are the pump and fan energy consumptions, respectively; E p , n o m , E f , n o m shown in Table 1 are the nominal values at the nominal flow rates based on the equipment specification. p 0 ~ p 3 and f0 –f3 are the parameters to be identified by collected operation data and the fitted values are presented in Table 2 . Similarly, the ratio of current desiccant solution flow rate m s and rated desiccant solution flow rate m s , n o m is defined as r p . The ratio between current air flow rate m a and nominal air flow rate ma,nom is defined as r f . The total energy consumption of dehumidifier can be described in Eq. (9). The validation of the energy models for the three energy consuming components has been analyzed and reported in the previous work [16]. (9) E total = E c + E p + E f 3 ANFIS predictive model development for the dehumidifier To develop an optimal control strategy considering system dynamic response and energy efficiency, it is crucial and essentialto develop a control-oriented model for predicting the system dynamic behaviors and characteristics between system input variables and output variables. However, due to the inherent nonlinear characteristics during the heat and mass transfer processes and the complex energy conversion among the components of a dehumidifier, it is quite a challenge to build mechanism model with constraints, complex model structure, and high computation cost to meet the real-time requirements. In present work, a dehumidifier model based on ANFIS is developed to predict system outputs (air temperature and humidity ratio) dynamically under varying control actions. Experimental input/output dynamic data sets collected from a wide operating range are employed to train the model parameters to improve the model prediction accuracy. As an intelligent modeling method integrating both neural networks and fuzzy logic principles, ANFIS [31,32] has advantages over other modeling methods with capabilities of self-adaptation, self-learning to approximate nonlinear functions and suitable application to dynamic control. The Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) based on Takagi-Sugeno model achieves fuzzification, fuzzy inference and defuzzification by neural networks. The mixed algorithms of back propagation algorithm and least square method are used to adjust premise parameters and conclusion parameters, and can automatically generate if-then rules. A typical ANFIS structure showed in Fig. 2 consists of five layers [33]. The first layer maps the input variables x i to the fuzzy set F j i and outputs the membership degree of the corresponding fuzzy set. The second layer outputs algebraic products of all input signals and each node M i represents the excitation intensity ω i of a rule. The incentive intensity of each rule is normalized in the third layer. In the next layer, the output y i related to each rule is calculated. The final output layer calculates the sum of all incoming signals as the total output Y . From the above-mentioned modeling method, a Takagi-Sugeno based fuzzy model with a set of if-then rules is presented to identify the relationship between input and output data adaptively, as described, R i : i f Y ( k - 1 ) i s F 1 i , Y ( k ) i s F 2 i , a n d U ( k - 1 ) i s F 3 i , a n d U ( k ) i s F 4 i then Y i ( k + 1 ) = λ 1 i Y ( k - 1 ) + λ 2 i Y ( k ) + λ 3 i U ( k - 1 ) + λ 4 i U ( k ) Y = y 1 y 2 , U = u 1 u 2 , λ i = λ 1 i λ 2 i λ 3 i λ 4 i where y 1 and y 2 are controlled variables which represent outlet air temperature and humidity ratio, respectively; u 1 and u 2 are manipulated variables which denote inlet desiccant solution flow rate and temperature, respectively; F 1 i - F 4 i are fuzzy sets of the ith Rule for different variables; λ i is a vector of the influence coefficients obtained from adaptive learning method; x T = y 1 k - 1 , y 1 k , y 2 k - 1 , y 2 k , u 1 k - 1 , u 1 k , u 2 k - 1 , u 2 k T is the vector of the system premise and each element corresponds to a membership value μ according to the membership function; k is the sample time. After training by several groups of experimental data under diverse running conditions, dozens of fuzzy rules can be acquired. Each rule corresponds to fitness α i which affects the final output related to the value of the membership function [34]. The outputs can be calculated by Eqs. (10) and (11). In the experiment, some step changes are deliberately performed on control variables as inlet solution flow rate and temperature by regulating the solution pump and chiller to get the enough excitation and system dynamic responses of the LDAC system. The values of outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are collected by the equipped sensors and transmitters whose specifications are shown in Table 4 . Some lower and upper limitations of variables are shown in Table 5 . The inlet air flow rate is assumed unchanged and the change of desiccant solution concentration is neglected. The simulation cases are conducted to compare the outputs of the prediction model and experimental data to verify the accuracy of the proposed model for LDAC. Dynamic operating data collected from the platform with 1 minute sampling interval are used to train and verify the developed model. Experimental data are divided into two parts, one part is used for model training and the other for model validation. In this work, Relative Error (RE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) as the evaluation indices of the model accuracy, are employed. (12) R E i = y real i - y calc i y real i × 100 % (13) RMSE = ∑ i = 1 N y real i - y calc i 2 N (14) MAE = ∑ i = 1 N y real i - y calc i N The comparisons of the predictive outlet air states using the proposed model and experimental measurements are shown in Fig. 5 , in which the red line with asterisk characters (*), represents the experimental data collected from actual experimental cases and the blue dotted line represents the outlet air state predicted by the proposed model. It can be found that the predictive outputs agree well with the experimental dynamic outputs. The accuracy of the proposed predictive model is summarized by using three evaluation indices RE, RMSE, and MAE, as listed in Table 6 . The relative errors of the outlet air state are shown in Fig. 6 where the outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are lower than 2% and 4%, respectively. The RMSE is 0.10 °C for outlet air temperature and 0.06 g/kg dry air for outlet air humidity ratio. Thus, the proposed model trained by ANFIS is capable of predicting the relationship accurately between the control signals and output results of the air state from LDAC. It can also be found in Fig. 4 that remarkable changes occur at around 60 minute. The relative errors of the outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are still small, which indicate that the developed ANFIS model can adapt the dynamic working conditions well. The variation trends of outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are nearly consistent over the time, which reveals that the heat and mass transfer are coupled in the dehumidification process. It can be observed that the solution temperature rises obviously at 155 minute while it takes a few minutes for the LDAC system to reach another new steady state. Thus, it reveals that the LDAC is a slow dynamic system. 5 Prescription of control schemes As analyzed from Section 4, the liquid desiccant dehumidifier is a slow dynamic Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) system with nonlinear characteristic and constraints, making the MPC, a widely used technique in many fields, as the suitable control method to be applied. However, in conventional MPC, only tracking error and control efforts are considered with the system efficiency ignored. In this section, an EMPC strategy is developed to control the dehumidifier system outputs as the required tracking trajectory and to achieve the improved energy efficiency and economic performance by solving an optimization problem considering system energy consumption for each time interval of a receding horizon. Fig. 7 illustrates the proposed EMPC control block scheme for the liquid desiccant dehumidifier. 5.1 Objective function Three costs are considered when the objective function is formed, namely, tracking error cost, control efforts rate cost and energy consumption cost under finite time domain. In a given D ( k , H p ) representing the time horizon starting from k time instant with length of prediction horizon H p , let y ref ( k , H p ) = y ref ( k + i | k ) : i = 0 , ⋯ H p and y ( k , H p ) = y ( k + i | k ) : i = 0 , ⋯ H p to be the sets of tracking values and outlet air conditions of LDAC, respectively, where y ref ( k + i | k ) = [ y 1 , r e f ( k + i | k ) , y 2 , r e f ( k + i | k ) ] i = 0 , ⋯ H p and y ( k + i | k ) = [ y 1 ( k + i | k ) , y 2 ( k + i | k ) ] i = 0 , ⋯ H p denote the current and future tracking values and system outlet values for outlet air temperature y 1 and humidity ratio y 2 at the time instant k. The sequence of control actions with a length of control horizon H c is denoted by u ( k , H c ) = u ( k + j | k ) : j = 0 , ⋯ H c where H c ⩽ H p and u ( k + j | k ) = [ u 1 ( k + j | k ) , u 2 ( k + j | k ) ] j = 0 , ⋯ H c is the current and future control actions for solution temperature u 1 and mass flow rate u 2 at time instant k and the increment of control actions for each time instant k is Δ u ( k + j | k ) = [ u ( k + j | k ) - u ( k - 1 + j | k ) ] ( j = 0 , 1 ⋯ , H c ) . The three above costs in D ( k , H p ) can be described as, C 1 ( k , H p ) = y ( k , H p ) - y ref ( k , H p ) Q 2 , for tracking error cost, C 2 ( k , H c ) = Δ u ( k + j | k ) R 2 , for control efforts cost, and C 3 ( k , H p ) = P · E total ( k , H p ) , for energy consumption cost. Q , R denote the diagonal weighting matrices corresponding to output offset and control increment, respectively. They are all real numbers which are used to judge the importance of input and output in the optimization performance function. P is a positive real number to adjust the weighting of energy consumption. x Q 2 = x T Qx denotes the weighted norm with the positive weighting matrix Q . Therefore, the receding horizon optimization problem of LDAC over the interval D ( k , H p ) can be expressed as follows. (15) J ( k , H c , H p ) = C 1 ( k , H p ) + C 2 ( k , H c ) + C 3 ( k , H p ) 5.2 Constraints The constraints concern the system dynamic equations, limitations of outputs, control actions, and their change rate. (16) y 1 ( k ) = f ( u 1 ( k - 1 ) , u 1 ( k ) , u 2 ( k - 1 ) , u 2 ( k ) , y 1 ( k - 1 ) , y 2 ( k - 1 ) ) (17) y 2 ( k ) = h ( u 1 ( k - 1 ) , u 1 ( k ) , u 2 ( k - 1 ) , u 2 ( k ) , y 1 ( k - 1 ) , y 2 ( k - 1 ) ) (18) y min ⩽ y ( k + i ) ⩽ y max i = 0 , ⋯ H p (19) u min ⩽ u ( k + j ) ⩽ u max j = 0 , ⋯ H c (20) Δ u min ⩽ Δ u ( k + j ) ⩽ Δ u max j = 0 , ⋯ H c Then the constrained optimization problem Ω can be summarized as follows, (21) u opt ( k ) = arg min u 1 ( k ) , u 2 ( k ) J ( k , H c , H p ) s . t . y 1 ( k ) = f ( u ( k ) , u ( k - 1 ) , y ( k - 1 ) ) y 2 ( k ) = h ( u ( k ) , u ( k - 1 ) , y ( k - 1 ) ) y ∈ [ y min , y max ] u ∈ [ u min , u max ] Δ u ∈ [ Δ u min , Δ u max ] y ( 0 ) = y 0 u ( 0 ) = u 0 At each sample time, a series of optimal control behaviors u opt ( k ) are calculated by solving the above optimization problem, yet only the first control action is implemented on the plant. 5.3 Genetic solver of the optimization function To obtain the optimal solution of an above dynamic receding-horizon optimization problem with nonlinear constraints, GA is employed due to its benefits in gradient computation free, low risk of local optimum and strong ability to handle nonlinearity. At each time instant, GA is implemented to determine the optimal control sequence of the dynamic flow rate m s , i n ( k ) and temperature T s , i n ( k ) of the inlet desiccant solution by solving the problem Ω . After initialization population of candidate solutions, selection, crossover, and mutation are performed based on the evaluated individuals to evolve the next generation from the current generation during each iteration. Size of population, maximum generations, and termination tolerance are assigned as 100, 160 and 1 × 10 - 6 , respectively. The complete algorithm of the proposed method is presented in Algorithm 1. Algorithm 1: The specific genetic algorithm to search the optimal solutions 1. Generate the initial individuals randomly 2. Determine the selection probability equally for all individuals 3. While the termination condition is false do 4. Calculate the fitness value of each individual 5. Calculate the selected probability according to roulette wheel methods 6. Save the selected individuals 7. Calculate the probability of crossover and mutation from selected individuals 8. Perform the crossover and mutation operators 9. Obtain a new generation 10. End while 6 Simulation analysis and discussions 6.1 Case study In order to show the performance in dynamic control and energy efficiency improvement of the proposed EMPC strategy for the dehumidifier, two scenarios, such as step response scenario and trajectory-tracking scenario, are considered. In each scenario, the time intervals for sampling and control are simulated as 2 minutes. The prediction horizon, the receding control horizon for the EMPC strategy are set to 4 and 3, respectively. The scenario 1 costs more simulation time for the reason that it takes some time to observe a dynamic process reach to another desired steady state of the outlet air. When the dynamic process reaches the expected steady state, the next step change process can be started. Thus, the total time of the whole processes and states simulation costs 350 minutes. The scenario 2 merely simulates the trajectory-tracking performance, which contains the tendency of continuous changes of outlet air states. For saving the calculating time, we spend half an hour on trajectory-tracking simulation on the premise of meeting the demand. The classical PI control strategy under the same required outlet air conditions are simulated to compare the performance of trajectory tracking and energy savings of the LDAC system with different control strategies. Scenario 1. Step response performance The case aimed to study the step response performance and the energy consumption for LDAC. The air state of a room is set to a suitable value by occupants according to their requirements, represented by black solid lines w1 and w2 in Fig. 8 . In most situations, the set points of the air state will not be changed frequently once they are determined. From the step profiles, initially, the required air temperature and humidity ratio are 16.5 °C and 7.2 g/kg, respectively. Then the outlet air temperature was required to rise from 16.5 °C to 17.3 °C, simultaneously with the required outlet air humidity ratio increasing from 7.2 g/kg to 7.5 g/kg. After that, the conditions are set back to the initial state. Then, the outlet air temperature is reduced to 15 °C and the outlet air humidity ratio down to 6.3 g/kg. Thus, both rising and decreasing conditions are considered and simulated in this scenario. Two control strategies, the presented EMPC and PI control, are simulated to control the output air conditions of the liquid desiccant dehumidifier with required step profiles within the acceptable errors. The outlet air temperature and humidity responses by these two control strategies are presented in Fig. 8, as blue dashed lines for EMPC and red dotted dash lines for PI control strategy. As shown in the figure, both PI and EMPC strategies can stabilize the outlet air temperature and humidity with acceptable steady state error. For temperature control, EMPC is with less lag time and less overshoot. The maximal relative error of outlet air temperature is 3% for EMPC and 10% for PI control at the dynamic step segments at 84 minute and 248 minute. For humidity control, in addition to the above advantages, EMPC approach showed better control performance than PI with smaller offset. The maximum of EMPC offset from the reference humidity ratio is about 0.38 g/kg and that of PI is 0.97 g/kg. It seems from the step responses that the regulation speed of EMPC is faster than PI for control outlet air temperature and humidity. It can be found that regulation of air temperature and humidity works 2 minutes in advance, as shown the zoomed view in Fig. 8 while there are about 2 minutes time delay for PI control. That is because in EMPC, changes of required air conditions in finite horizon time are introduced in the receding optimization problem so that the changes can be handled in advanced before they actually happen. Also, there is less vibration near the steady-state values for the EMPC approach. That is because that the control actions and their changing rate are considered during receding optimization procedure of proposed EMPC strategy and some control attempts leading to outputs vibrations can be given up. Control actions in EMPC and PI strategies, the changes in the inlet solution temperature and flow rate for Scenario 1 are shown in Fig. 9 . Solution flow rate is almost unchanged during the small step before 162 minutes and remarkable adjust exists during the large step changes after 244 minutes. It concludes that the solution temperature has greater influence on the outlet air states than solution flow rate. For the PI controller, the solution flow rate is nearly unchanged (refer to the zoomed view in Fig. 9) and the solution temperature is regulated with different required outlet air conditions. Nevertheless, EMPC strategy will choose control actions with smaller solution rate and lower temperature to save energy from the chiller side. Moreover, from Fig. 9, adjustments of the solution flow rate and temperature are performed at around the 240th minute which are 4 minutes before required air conditions are changed. The energy consumptions of dehumidifier under the two control strategies have also been compared in Fig. 10 based on the developed energy consumption model. It can be concluded from the figure that there exists considerable energy savings by employing the EMPC strategy. Maximum 13.4% and average 6.8% energy savings can be obtained due to the consideration of energy consumption while developing the objective function in the receding optimization problem Ω . From Fig. 10, over 5% energy saving can be reached at the steady segments with higher air state set points and more than 10% energy saving with lower air state set points. Thus, the presented EMPC strategy can achieve higher energy efficiency improvement under lower air state set points. The detailed analysis is shown in Fig. 11 . To show the different energy saving potentials under different setting conditions, we compare the dynamic energy saving performance with four segment types. Fig. 10 displays the four representative segments, namely high set point period (from 130 to 142 minutes), low set point period (from 304 to 316 minutes), step down period (from 162 to 164 minutes), and step up period (from 80 to 82 minutes). Fig. 11 shows the energy saving percentages of different time segments. It can be observed that low set point segment obtains 11.2% energy saving which nearly twice higher than that of the high set point segment. The step direction also has significant influence on the energy efficiency. Fig. 11 shows that 8.6% energy saving in step up period is higher than that in the step down period. In the step down period, the energy consumptions of the two strategies are nearly the same for the reason that much more energy will be simultaneously consumed at this moment to try to reach lower air conditions as soon as possible. To sum up, the energy efficiency improvement for EMPC of liquid desiccant dehumidifier depends on the air state set points and step direction as shown in Table 7 . Scenario 2. Trajectory-tracking performance The second scenario illustrates the tracking and energy saving performance under trajectory changes of required outlet air temperature and humidity, as shown by black solid lines in Fig. 12 . The desired outlet air temperature is decreasing from 16.2 °C to 13.8 °C while the outlet air humidity ratio is decreasing from 6.6 g/kg to 5.7 g/kg during the first 15 minutes. Then, the outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are required to be unchanged for about 7 minutes. After that, the outlet air temperature and humidity ratio are desired to increase from 13.8 °C to 15 °C, and 5.7 g/kg to 6.3 g/kg, respectively. Both the proposed EMPC and PI strategies are performed under the trajectory changing conditions. Fig. 12 displays the tracking response profiles of outlet air temperature and humidity ratio with blue dotted line representing EMPC tracking profiles while PI tracking profiles represented by red dotted dash lines. It can be easily observed that the EMPC strategy shows better trajectory-tracking performance for outlet air temperature and humidity in smaller tracking errors compared with PI control strategy under the same trajectory changing. Energy consumptions by the two control strategies are compared in Fig. 13 . Conclusions can be drawn that the energy consumption by EMPC is lower than that by PI control strategy except for the initial period of time. From Fig. 13, there is hardly any difference upon the energy consumptions of the LDAC between the two control strategies in the first few minutes due to the same initial set air conditions. The average energy saving can reach up to 9.5%. It can be concluded that the energy-saving effect is also considered under the varying air conditions. 6.2 Energy efficiency analysis The energy consumptions of related energy-consuming components in the LDAC system, chiller and pump in both operation strategies are discussed in this section. It should be noted that the inlet air flow rate is assumed unchanged mentioned in model validation section, thus the energy consumption of the fan is not discussed. Figs. 14 and 15 show the COPs of the chiller and energy consumptions of the chiller and pump in respective scenarios. From Fig. 14, it can be easily found that the energy consumption of chiller accounts for a large proportion of the total system energy consumption. The energy consumptions of pump by both operation strategies keep nearly the same. The system energy efficiency improvement in scenario 1 can achieve total 50.98 kW energy reduction from the chiller throughout the simulation. Especially, the COP of the chiller can reach higher at low air set points (from 304 to 316 minutes) than that at high air set points (from 130 to 142 minutes). In Fig. 15, there is total 12.65 kW energy saving of the chiller by the EMPC strategy throughout the simulation. In the initial period of time (from 0 to 3 minutes), the COPs of the chiller by both operation strategies are nearly equal due to the same initial air states. In both scenarios, it is apparent that the proposed EMPC strategy can improve the COP of the chiller comparing with the conventional PI strategy whether under step changes of air states or dynamic variations of air states. From the two scenarios, the results show that EMPC strategy can achieve the air temperature and humidity as the occupants’ requirements and improve energy efficiency under various working conditions comparing with PI strategy. The PI strategy mainly focuses on dynamic response characteristic like settling time, overshoot and steady state error instead of the system energy consumption. With the exception of dynamic response characteristic, the system energy consumption is also considered in the dynamic optimization objective of EMPC strategy. Especially, during the receding optimization process at each sample time, the optimization control actions achieving the requirements of air state and decreasing the system energy consumption as much as possible are calculated to control the solution pump and chiller. In addition, the energy efficiency improvement of the liquid desiccant dehumidifier by EMPC strategy depends on the air conditions like the air state set points and step direction. 7 Conclusion This paper proposed an EMPC strategy based on ANFIS dynamic model for the purpose of system dynamic operation and energy efficiency improvements of LDAC system. LDAC dynamic model and energy consumption models were established to predict the outputs and total energy consumption of the LDAC system, respectively. Then, a receding optimization problem based on EMPC strategy was developed by considering the tracking error, control efforts rate, and system energy efficiency as the objective functions. The proposed EMPC strategy and conventional PI strategy have been compared in two simulation scenarios with the energy efficiency analysis as well. From the simulation results, the conclusions can be summarized as follows: (1) The developed predictive model was validated by experimental data and the results show that ANFIS based modelling method for liquid desiccant dehumidifier is effective to predict system dynamic outputs with the relative errors lower than 2% and 4% for the outlet air temperature and humidity ratio, respectively, and with few computation efforts. This modeling method can be suitably applied to optimal operation strategy development of LDAC. (2) It can be concluded that EMPC strategy performs good outputs with smaller tracking error, faster response, and higher energy efficiency than the PI control strategy under different air state conditions. Meanwhile, thanks to the proposed EMPC strategy can achieve up to 9.5% energy savings by considering energy consumption during receding optimization. (3) The energy efficiency improvement for EMPC of liquid desiccant dehumidifier depends on the air state set points and step direction. Low set points can reach 11.2% energy saving which nearly twice higher than that of the high set points. The air states change in step up period can obtain 8.6% energy saving, which is higher than that in the step down period. (4) The COP of the chiller have a big impact on the system energy efficiency due to the large proportion of its energy consumption. EMPC tries to find the optimal control actions that with higher chiller COP, so that the overall system energy efficiency can be improved. Declaration of Competing Interest None. coredata.dc:description: As a good alternative to cooling-based air dehumidification, Liquid Desiccant Air Conditioning (LDAC) has drawn increasing attention for energy saving in large-scale public buildings. However, available investigations mostly pay attention to the dehumidification performance analysis and optimization based on steady-state models. Dynamic control issues for LDAC are rather important to the system performance and economic cost under the changing working conditions, such as the changing setting points of indoor air conditions and sensible/latent loads in occupied space. In this study, a dynamic model based on the Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) method is established to describe the system output air temperature and humidity ratio of LDAC dynamically with varied input conditions. The verification results show that a good agreement can be found between the prediction results from the proposed model and the experimental data with the relative errors less than 2% for outlet air temperature and less than 4% for outlet air humidity ratio, respectively. An EMPC strategy is designed based on the proposed dynamic model for LDAC by solving a receding optimization problem considering tracking error, control efforts rate, and energy consumption as the objective functions with Genetic Algorithm (GA) to get optimal dynamic response and improve the energy efficiency as well. The simulation analysis shows the proposed EMPC strategy outperforms Proportional–Integral (PI) control with smaller tracking error, faster response, and higher energy efficiency. The average energy saving by the proposed EMPC strategy can reach up to 9.5%.
coredata.dc:title: Dynamic modeling and economic model predictive control of a liquid desiccant air conditioning
